author: .paulharris
content:
Just using host name to do security isn't actually secure (easy to workaround via hosts entry for example) so because it's a privileged connection, having a JWT offers a level of security...
Having said that, it also depends how the token is used... if it's in an authorization header in http it's not actually very secure either, which is why keymanager-api ended up requiring https... but it's probably outside the scope of your question...
